bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to the Medical Officer in Charge, U.S. Public Health Service, Memphis, Tennessee, March 1, 1923

div1.p: Griffitts writes that he has surveyed a power company pond and makes recommendations for malaria prevention measures.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to the Medical Officer in Charge, U.S. Public Health Service, Memphis, Tennessee, March 1, 1923
div1.opener:
IMPOUNDED WATER.-- Griffitts.
Pond of Houston Power Co., near Newton, Dale Co., Ala.
Copy for
Dr. Carter
IHDG
F.I. MALARIA
U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
MAR -2 1923
RECEIVED
519 Dexter Avenue,
Montgomery, Alabama,
March 1, 1923.
Medical Officer in Charge,
Field Investigations of Malaria,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Memphis, Tenn.
Sir:
div1.p:
The dam of the Houston Power Company, located on the Little
Choctawhatchee River, six miles below the town of Newton, Dale
County, was closed in January, 1921, and the area to be flooded
was not cleared. For the most part, it was wooded territory, there
was such brush, tree-tops(felled) and old logs.

In August, 1920, citizens of that community, anticipating
unhealthful conditions following the making if the pond, peti-
tioned the Alabama State Board of Health to cause action that
might protect them. Accordingly, the following recommendations
were made by the State Board of Health, after a preliminary
survey by Asistant Sanitary Engineer J.C. Carter.-

"1. A hatchery for the raising of top minnows (Gambusia aff-
inis) to be established at once. Sufficient minnows can
be collected in the various streams near the dam site to
start this hatchery. The minnows raised in the hatchery
are to be placed in the lake made by the dam, at inter-
vals throughout the year and in sufficient quantities to
control mosquito breeding. The hatchery should be con-
structed near the lake, but at a height that will pre-
vent an overflow from the main stream.

"2 All brush and vegetation under six inches in diame-
ter to be removed between a line twenty foot out from
the seventy-five feet contour line to a line sufficient-
ly far toward the main stream that the brush at full
growth will not protrude above the surface of the water.

"3. All trees or growth above six inches in diameter,
extending from the seventy-five feet contour line to
a line fifty feet outward to be ringed. The trees and
other growth standing in the water will die after one
or two years. It will be necessary to patrol this area
at intervals to see that no flotage collects on the trees
or other growth.
2-- Imp. Wat. Newton, Ala.

"4. At certain seasons when the water in the lake recedes
some water may be left in depressions. Such places must be
drained by ditches constructed as soon as practicable af-
ter the water in the main body has receded.

" Special attention should be paid to the streams and ditch-
es which enter the lake fromtthe hills. Still water which
is very favorable to the breeding of mosquitoes is apt to
be found in such places. These places must be kept clean
of all growth and flotage to enable the mosquito-destroying
fish to work freely.

“Inspections should be made from time to time after the
water is damned, and such recommendations as may be necessary,
due to the change of conditions, be made.”

None of the above recommendations was carried out, save the stock-
ing with top-minnows (gambusia). The Power Company claims they did not
get the written recommendations.

During the Fall of the first year of this uncleared pond, there
was a decided rise in the prevalence of malaria in the territory
contiguous thereto. The following summer and Fall (1922), this prev-
alence reached epidemic proportions. Several investigators for the
State Board of Health visited the community, made rapid surveys of
the shores of the pond, house-to-house canvass to determine the
amount of malaria and supplied quinine to the people.

As to the prevalence of malaria, it was ascertained that of a
population of 199, approximately 176 had malaria, with one death.

Toward the late season of 1922 there was a rather heavy infes-
tation of hedges with A. quadrimaculatus, but of the rapid exam-
inations of the shores of the pond, comparatively little breeding
was found. No extra-pond breeding was found to explain the infestiv-
ity. The body of the pond was not sufficiently examined to base
an opinion on as to the part it played in production.

It being the desire of the State Health Officer, Dr. S.W. Welch,
that there be applied such knowledge as we now have, and may be
able to acquire, to the prevention of malaria within the influ-
ence of this and other ponds, I have selected this pond as one on
which to conduct studies, including those of control methods, dur-
ing the coming season.

Preliminary surveys have been made and memoranda concerning
conditions and measures to be inaugurated submitted to the
Mr. G.H. Haslehurst, Chief State Sanitary Engineer, State Board of
Health. These memoranda are respectfully submitted as a part of
this report-- appended hereto, (Exhibit “A”)

When further data are collected, report of this project will
be submitted on the prescribed blanks--“Original Survey of Im-
pounded Water”.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, T.H.D. Griffitts,
Epidemiologist. Incl.2cc, 5p Mem.

div1.p: Exhibit “A” Houston P.Co.

Memorandum to Chief Sanitary Engineer, G. H. Haslehurst,
in re malaria investigation and prevention on pond of Houston
Power Company, Little Choctawhatchee River, six miles south of
Newton. - 2/24/23

1. Surveys made on this pond on February 6th, 20th, 21st,
and 22nd, 1923, showed that there is free Anopheline breeding
in practically all favorable places along the shores of the main
body, as well as banks of islands.

On February 6th, it was not difficult dipping from the
shore and 8 or 10-feet away from the shore in collections of
flotage-particularly pine bark, pine needles, and small stick
flotage, to find Anopheline larvae, all sizes, particularly those
under three-fourths developed. The bight designated on the map
as B1R (meaning bight 1 right bank), was found on February 6th,
to be breeding very freely from 1 to 10 larvae at a dip in
selected flotage collections. This was a cold rainy day and
the main body of the pond was not examined.

On February 20th, just two weeks following the previous
examination, in this same bight, breeding was found to be very
free - might say profuse - approximately 60 larvae of all sizes
and about 8 pupae were collected within about an hours time.
On the previous morning isolated side pools were completely frozen
over and ice skirted the banks of the pond so that the water, at
the time of examination, was icy cold.

Following the right shore line from this bight upward,
very little breeding was found in the old field with grassy
- 2 -
banks, but in the protected bights where drifts and flotage
were collected, both along the shore and 8 or 10-feet away,
larvae of all sizes were collected.

This shore was examined on this side up to McSwain's
Bridge. Many Gambusia were observed, ranging from one-half to
full grown, and they were particularly active in the shallow water
in the old field between B1R and B2R. However, they were noticed
in smaller numbers in the wooded section.

Three streams that discharge into upper ends of
bights on the right side of the pond between McSwain's bridge
and (B1R) carry a great deal of sand. By removing some of the
log and brush obstructions, these bights will be obliterated
in a relatively short time. This should be done.

2. Examination on the left shore and bights gave some-
what similar results, but the heaviest breeding noted along the
shore was in BIR.

3. Examination of the Body of the Pond. Wherever flotage
of pine bark, pine needles, and small stick flotage was collected
against logs, particularly old logs that are growing grasses and
weeds - and these can be found over a good portion of the pond -
Anopheline production is taking place. Many large larvae and
pupae were collected from such places and in many instances on
submerging large pieces of pine bark, larvae wiggled away and
a regular summer time collection was made.
NOTE: No Gambusia were noted any distance away from the shore.

4. Prevention of Anopheline Production. To remove
the flotage necessary for prevention of Anopheline production
on this pond would be so expensive that it would not be reason-
able to expect the Power Company to do it. I do not believe
it reasonably possible to prevent the entire production of
Anophelines on this pond during the coming summer. The best
that we can hope to accomplish, is a decided reduction in the
production, and to this end, I would recommend the following:

(a) That brush and flotage along the shore of
B1R be dragged out sufficiently far that it would not wash
back into the lake.

NOTE. Breeding in this bight perhaps affects more people
than that of any other single place. Other bights on the right
bank and along the shore in the wooded section, where logs and
brush are collecting flotage, should also be taken care of in
the same way as B1R.

In addition, small brush for a few feet out in the
water and, say 5-feet on the land, should be removed where
necessary so that one can get through for inspecting the shore.
This latter should be done only where necessary to facilitate
inspections and the removal of collections of flotage ashore.

(b) The left bank should be similarly taken care
of and only in places where there are log-jams and much flotage.

(c) In order to make it more nearly possible
to inspect the body of this pond, and to facilitate the use of
- 4 -
paris green, it will be necessary to clean out a way for
getting through with a boat. It is therefore recommended
that an opening be made from the old channel or open part
of the pond to the shore line on each side, say about 8 to
10-feet wide, and these places spaced about 1000 feet apart
from above the dam to McSwain's bridge. Much of this brush
can be beaten down with a pole or paddle, but in many places,
logs will have to be chopped into and turned around so as to
allow the boat to get through. Aside from the immediate
cleaning of BIR, it is suggested that the lateral channels
be provided as soon as possible. We will attempt to devise
a method of applying paris green to this pond just as soon
as these runs are opened up.

(d) The area of the pond above McSwain's bridge
is certainly an A. Punctipennis breeding area and may produce
Quadrimaculatus. At the present time, however, there is
perceptible current for a short distance below the bridge.
This area should be taken care of after the work on the lower
portion of the pond is progressing.

(e) It is suggested that the Houston Power
Company be advised that within the next two weeks this work
be started, and that they notify you when they are ready, so
that we may advise them on the ground in order that only the
necessary work be done. Their Mr. Spigner was with me on the
investigation - he should now be familiar in a general way ofwith
the places requiring clearing and the way to do it. It is
*These will be spaced as close as necessary
later on.

not feasible to clean extensive areas - only the worst
places at reasonable expense.
div1.closer:
Respectfully submitted, T. H. D. Griffitts,
Epidemiologist,
U. S. Public Health Service. 1955*
